title: Why doesn't the government stop charging interest on student loans when many student loans have doubled in size? (100,000 debt turn into 200,000 and then 400,000 and then 800,000) When will it end? - Quora

response.answer_text: The fundamental problem with government student loans isn’t the rate of interest being charged. The most an undergraduate student can borrow in federal student loans over four years is $27,000. Currently, the interest rate is a ridiculously low 2.75%. The real issues with federal student loans are, in this order, the federal student loan system, your parents, and you. The System The system is based on the illogical principle that, “Everyone is entitled to go to college.” The federal government will loan money, at an outrageously low rate, to almost any high school graduate, who is a US citizen, to pay for college. Their major, marketable or not, doesn’t matter. By and large, their academic ability doesn’t matter. (In the US almost any high school graduate can find a four-year institution that will accept them and their parent’s money.) That’s the “system.” It is stupid. However, everybody acts surprised, and “gets their nose out of joint,” when student loans can’t be repaid. Two out of three students who matriculate are either going to drop out or end up underemployed. They are going to have a tough time paying off their student loans. Many of these students didn’t have any business, academically, being in college. Your Parents After the federal government, I blame the parents. Thomas B Walsh's answer to Why do many people in the US have lots of students loans? You I don’t put much of the blame on you. You were naive teenagers when you made the dumb decisions that got you into a financial mess with student loans. But, Holy Cow! You graduated high school without understanding compound interest? You didn’t bother reading the terms of the loans when you signed up for them? You felt so damn entitled, you gave no thought to what your family could afford to pay for your post-secondary education? Sorry, some of this falls on you. Notes Case in point. From the question, you don’t even understand the difference between a federal student loan and a private student loan.

For the 70% of students who take on loans, the average loan at graduation is a bit under $30,000. The interest rates run as high as about 6.8%, but most are much lower. Current loans are offered at 2.75%. If you paid nothing on your student loans, it would take 22 years to hit $100,0000 and 58 years to hit $800,000. Of course, penalties can add more, but those will only happen if you don’t meet income guidelines or don’t work with you loan servicer. For undergraduate education, the US federal government will not loan anyone $100,000 for one degree. Most students are limited to a hair over $30,000.
